fields.label_text:
Silver Gallery:
The standing dish or tazza served food. The foot of this one is decorated with grelots (small globular bells), possibly an emblem of the family that once owned it. The central medallion depicts Lucretia stabbing herself, a scene ending the story from legendary history of early Rome, The Rape of Lucretia. 
The peapod-ornament in the dish, popular from about 1600 to 1650, was a feature of the work of the goldsmith Juan de Herrera.

fields.physical_description: In the centre of the bowl is a medallion showing Lucretia stabbing herself, outside which is a band chased with floral spray; baluster stem and base decorated with embossed grelots and engraved strap work.
fields.dimensions: Diameter: 10.30 cm foot, Height: 13.00 cm, Length: 22.10 cm
fields.label:
Silver Gallery:
The standing dish or tazza served food. The foot of this one is decorated with grelots (small globular bells), possibly an emblem of the family that once owned it. The central medallion depicts Lucretia stabbing herself, a scene ending the story from legendary history of early Rome, The Rape of Lucretia. 
The peapod-ornament in the dish, popular from about 1600 to 1650, was a feature of the work of the goldsmith Juan de Herrera. [26/11/2002]
fields.marks: Inside rim: maker’s mark of Miguel Jeronimo Monegro, town mark for Seville: a tower above SEVILLE, assayer's mark of Juan de Herrera [Fernandez p62]
fields.bibliography:
Oman, Charles. <u>The Golden Age of Hispanic Silver: 1400-1665</u>. London: Her Majesty's Stationery Office, 1968).
See catalogue no. 66.
Cruz Valdovinos, José Manuel. <u>Cinco Siglos de Platería Sevillana</u>. Seville: Ayuntamiento, 1992. Catalogue of an exhibition at the Real Monasterio de San Clemente, Seville, 7 April - 30 May 1992. ISBN 8479520647
See catalogue no. 33 (pp. 54-5).
Sanz Serrano, María Jesús. La fuente de Lucrecia en el Museo Victoria y Alberto de Londres. <u>In</u>: <u>Homenaje al Profesor Hernández Perera</u>. Madrid: 1992, pp. 741-46.
Esteras Martín, Cristina. <u>Alorda-Derksen: la colección: platería de los siglos XIV-XVIII (obras escogidas) / Alorda-Derksen: The collection: silverwork from the 14th-18th centuries (selected works)</u>, bilingual Spanish/English edition. Barcelona and London: AD, 2005.
fields.history_note:
Despite being struck with a maker's and an assayer's mark in the bowl, the identity of the silversmith responsible for making this tazza has been the subject of debate. Charles Oman (1968: cat. entry 66) confidently deciphered them as the marks of 'Juan de Herrera' and 'Miguel Jeronimo Monegro', but as the bibliographical evidence he produced was inconclusive he declined to decide which of them was the maker. (According to Oman, the silversmith Monegro is first mentioned in 1544 and adds a codicil to his will in 1572; Herrera becomes head of the goldsmiths' guild in 1578 and dies in 1622.) In their guide to Spanish silver marks, Fernández, Munoa and Rabasco (1992: p. 62) identify Herrera as the assayer and Monegro as the silversmith.

The various interpretations and attributions were summarised in Cruz Valdovinos (1992, no. 33), who then argued that the mark usually interpreted as that of 'Miguel Jeronimo Monegro' should in fact be transcribed as the letters as IVº / MDNº, or  'Juan Maldonado', assayer in 1554. On the other hand, he reads the other mark as 'Herrera', as Oman had done. Unlike Oman, Cruz Valdovinos identifies 'Herrera' as the maker (in part because this mark is stamped in a different part of the bowl to the others), but he is unable to use documentary evidence and comparison with similar marks to identify the maker conclusively.

Nothing is know of the tazza's early ownership. It was exhibited at the South Kensington Museum Special Loan Exhibition of 1881, No.937 (where a similar piece, No. 355, from the Paul Recappe Collection was also exhibited).

Historical significance: This is a rare surviving example of a type of drinking vessel mentioned frequently in sixteenth-century inventories. For other Spanish examples of the same form, see Esteras Martín: 2005, cat. entry 11 (especially p. 92, n. 69) and p. 13, n. 1.
fields.historical_context_note: The tazza is a type of vessel referred to in contemporary Spanish inventories as 'a vessel to drink from with a low-relief medallion in the centre and a high foot' (Cruz Valdovinos: 1992, cat. no. 33). The bell motifs round the foot recall a similar form of ornament on a chalice made in Cuenca (now in the National Archeological Musem, Madrid), a similarity which suggests the close links between the goldsmiths' workshops of Seville and the Central Castilian town of Cuenca (Cruz Valdovinos: 1992, cat. no. 33).
